title: Del-Com Schools hires company to improve technology - Muncie Star Press
text:
Del-Com Schools hires company to improve technology Emma Kate Fittes , efittes@muncie.gannett.com 7:28 a.m. EDT September 18, 2015 Kurt Hostetler/The Star PressThe Indiana Department of Education recently announced its four star school nominations for the 2013-14 year. Among those selected were Delta High School and Royerton Elementary School in Delaware Community School District. (Photo: Kurt Hostetler/The Star Press) 5 CONNECT 12 TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
MUNCIE — A new federal grant could help Delaware Community Schools revamp its technology, and the district is willing to put nearly $10,000 into the application. 
Del-Com does not currently have a 1:1 technology to student ratio like some local districts, including Muncie and Yorktown Community Schools. 
Superintendent Reece Mann said in August that the district is planning on offering 1:1 technology soon, but first need the proper technology infrastructure. 
Last year the Universal Service Program for Schools and Libraries, also known as E-rate, made changes to help schools afford just that. The federal program now offers a second grant — known as Category 2 — every five years that assists public schools and libraries pay for things like firewalls, routers and wireless access points. 
E-rate also offers, and has offered for years, a Category 1 grant that helps schools and libraries pay for its basic bandwidth. 
Del-Com has hired a company to help the district with the grant application. 
Technology Dynamics will evaluate the district’s current technology infrastructure and put together a project plan, Mann said Tuesday. The company will also write a request for proposal, which the district needs to apply for the grant. 
The district is paying $9,980 from the Capital Project Fund to hire the technology consulting company to do the audit, money that won’t be returned to the fund even if Del-Com receives the grant. Mann said the grant money has to be put toward technology specifically. 
The board approved the payment Tuesday night. 
According to its website, the majority of Technology Dynamics projects have been for schools and universities, including Purdue University, Indiana State University, Indianapolis Public Schools and Anderson Community Schools. 
Mann had applied for the E-rate Category 2 grant while superintendent at Monroe Central Schools last year. 
Brent Headland, the technology director at Monroe Central, said he put together the request for proposal and project plan himself instead of using a company like Technology Dynamics. 
The district was approved for the grant a few months ago and new equipment — including new switches, fiber optic lines and wireless access points — is on its way, Headland said. Headland’s proposal for $150,000 was approved and the grant is reimbursing the school 80 percent of its spending. 
Monroe Central already has a technology infrastructure that supports its 1:1 technology-to-student ratio. Headland said it was included in a 2008 building project, but hasn’t been updated since. Ideally, it should be updated every five years, he said.
